conclusion: Understand the gravitational force exerted by a uniformly dense sphere and how it changes when a smaller sphere is removed.
Mass of the sphere is M, radius of the sphere is R, distance from the center of the sphere to the particle is 2R, and radius of the smaller sphere is R/2.
The gravitational force F exerted by a sphere of mass M and radius R on a particle at a distance r from the center is given by F = GM/r^2.
Substituting r = 2R into the formula, the gravitational force becomes F = GM/(2R)^2 = GM/4R^2.
The gravitational force exerted by the sphere after removing the smaller sphere is the force exerted by the sphere on the particle minus the force exerted by the smaller sphere on the particle.
The force exerted by the smaller sphere on the particle is F_smaller sphere = GM/(R/2)^2 = GM/(R^2/4) = 4GM/R^2.
The force exerted by the sphere on the particle is F_sphere = GM/4R^2.
The net force exerted by the sphere on the particle is F_net = F_sphere - F_smaller sphere = GM/4R^2 - 4GM/R^2.
Simplifying the expression for F_net: F_net = GM/4R^2 * (1 - 4/R^2) = GM/4R^2 * (R^2 - 4)/R^2 = GM(R^2 - 4)/(4R^2).
